title: Kenya: We Expend Too Much Energy On Sideshows
text:
Kenya: Cabinet Meets Over Teachers Strike opinion 
Sometimes I wonder how we manage to keep going as a country and even achieve a modicum of development. 
Look at all the noise that is going on about all kinds of things that touch on the very existence of our nation. 
The biggest and so far what has been the noisiest one is the teachers' strike. Who is right between the teachers and the government? 
All of us would agree that teachers do quite some serious work and need to be remunerated in a manner that gives them a sense of dignity. 
SIT AND NEGOTIATE 
One would, however, see some sense in what the government is saying. Paying them the percentages that the court has ordered would affect the national wage bill in a way that may not be sustainable. 
But both government and the teachers' unions are headed by human beings who one would expect have the interest of the Kenyan child at heart. 
Why would they not sit down and negotiate? A lot of time and energy has been wasted over three weeks now and no positive outcome is in sight. 
Schools have in fact been closed as we speak. 
Then there is the Anne Waiguru, Raila Odinga argument about a scandal at the National Youth Service and threats of taking each other to court. 
The good Cabinet secretary seems to have admitted that some money was lost through the corrupt behaviour of some officers in that department. 
CASE WITHDRAWN 
Mr Odinga insists politically that she ought to resign. He even says that she is being shielded by the president. 
Where is the truth in all this? May be we shall never get to know which is characteristic of Kenyan public discourse on corruption and other social ills. 
The deputy Inspector General of police was told to leave office and initially resisted that move. After finally leaving office she sued the government. 
Now we hear she has withdrawn the case. Before this matter came to an end we now have the matter of the deputy Chief Justice. 
After being told by the Judicial Service Commission that she has to retire at 70 she was not quite in agreement and went to court. It seems everyone is going to court. 
CONSTITUTION VIOLATION 
There is certainly too much noise to the point that one wonders what energy is left to build Kenya into a country that we can all be proud of. 
While Jubilee parliamentarians are rallying around Waiguru, the Cord ones are now focusing on the president. 
They want to impeach him on account of not honouring a court order. They say he has violated the Constitution which he took an oath to defend. 
I wonder what they would do in his position. Kenya lives on though. 
Fr Wamugunda is dean of students, University of Nairobi; Kenya
